ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Practical knowledge on education policy, grant proposals, Native ed programs, and factors that influence Native students and academic performance + cultural programs and policies

I learned about Native education, grants, scholarships and insight about how it can be improved to benefit the community. Most importantly, I learned about how education can be utilized by Indigenous scholars, nations, and tribes.

This course is great at preparing you for writing academic papers, grant proposals, and op-eds. It prepares you for relevant writing in the professional world outside of theoretically academic work. Besides receiving an important and robust understanding of Native ed policy, you'll be able to analyze studies and methods, discuss them, and propose your own ideas in class. Feedback is really thorough.
Critical thinking, analysis of government documents, grant-writing

I learned so much about Native educational policy, and factors for retention for Native students at all levels. I thought I knew a lot about this but Professor Makomenaw assigned readings that gave details on every topic, that were clear and informative and I learned so so much.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths were being able to learn from Dean M + other students experiences and knowledges and being able to be really creative with assignments.  Weakness: could be more practical writing assignments, like short policy memos or more program proposalsI really liked practicing writing them and doing them for assignments.

The prime strength of this course was learning about Indigenous narratives in education. One suggestion I have is having a policy brief switched to the 10 page final, and the grant writing to a 5-7 page to the midterm paper. There is just more to elaborate on with a policy brief.

Strengths - great structure of assignments and prof really listens to students like changing the last assignment to be a proposal for our final!!!! the organization of the lessons/weekly learning themes were really effective in helping non-native students and students with little knowledge of native education stay connected to the material and caught up with the complex topics
Weaknesses - during class, the occasional more structured lesson (get into groups to answer these questions, analyze this document together, etc) could have helped solidify the information from the readings

This class had incredibly practical assignments, a lesson plan and grant proposal and weekly challenges like finding non-deficit based articles on Native education that I was never bored, learned a lot but in a way I cared about.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Definitely a great class for edst people and those interested in practical ed policy.
I recommend this course to any Native student and education studies scholars. It is a strong example of how the education system interacts with marginalized communities, which must be explored.

Yes! Definitely take this course. The assignments are relevant and Prof. Makomenaw is very fair with deadlines and the work. You won't feel like you're doing any kind of busy work-- it's all relevant and important. The readings are very enlightening, and the lesson plan creation is fun.
Absolutely! Especially education or Indigenous studies people, but anyone who wants to learn more about this topic, it's comprehensive and informative and incredibly engaging.
